body:
consider what you are doing.. 450 em units divided by 16 em units -> 28.125 as em/em.. a ratio.. do you have a height of 450em and 16 "things" and want to know the height of the individual? then it will be 450em/16. If 16 is the font size height then 450em/16em is the number of lines that can fit on.. why does it make sense to set that on to the height?

> Using unit(450px, em) just outputs 450,

it doesn't, it outputs 450em on its own... how are you using it?

The intention of the unit maths is to a) give people the right unit and b) give people consistent units and improve the quality of the less by making the maths make sense.

Mostly because I want a consistent grid and unit throughout my CSS. I could set the height to 450px, but then I would have to change every px value if I change the base value (em). In this case I want to specify something in px, convert it to em based on my base value (in this case 16px). I still don't see why you would ever want to drop the unit for anything if it's specified in the original calculation.

You're right about unit, it just changes px to em, my bad. I was expecting a conversion but it's just a string replace of the unit really.

Edit:
I'll change to having the base value unitless and do all conversions with unit(pixel/base, em). Problem solved, but I still think the original division should be either fixed to not drop the unit, or updated in the docs to say that dividing will cause you to lose the original unit measurment.

It depends on what math you're doing (we never got full score for losing units back in school) ;)

You can't really say that 2em / 2em == 1, since that 1 doesn't really mean anything outside the scope of the calculation. To assume the math will always be done and that the unit will always be present where it is done seems weird to me. The fact that unit less values isn't valid in CSS should probably also be considered.

we sadly do not know how many px in a em unless in the browser. the convert function tries to convert rather than change the unit, but that also does not convert em and px - just deterministic things like cm to mm or rad to deg etc.

well 2em/2em is pretty meaningless too.. consider 2 pieces of string, each a certain length, then divide one by the other.. what you are saying is how many pieces of string fit into another piece of string.. that is a ratio, not a measurement, so it does not have a unit.

http://www.purplemath.com/modules/units.htm

@lukeapage  Since we are already discussing this, should this `(1cm/1mm)` cause to syntax error? I do not mind it and would not open feature request for it, but expressions topic is already here and it could theoretically result in `10`.

Well it seems the focus is more on units no one is using and less on actual use cases so feel free to close this one. Changing my less isn't hard, it's just a lot more bloated and messy now, something I wanted to avoid in the first place.
@tozz Do not judge less.js by what my comments focus at. I'm not less.js developer, I just stumbled into the same thing few day ago and read about it in some issue.

o_O  The way we add units has changed? I think I'm out of the loop on this one.

Doesn't this:

```
width: (2em/2em);
```

result in:

```
width: 1em;
```

?

Oh wow, just tried it, nope. What's the rationale?

I never had a problem with units or maths before. I see the rationale behind strict units/maths, but my recommendation is that we change the default to false for both, maybe until people have time to acclimate and we have the new docs up.

Yes maybe we should revisit this.. at least 1. Not throw errors 2. On tocss
if the units are canceled still output it since no units is invalid.. that
would give us the best of both worlds

I've been trying out the 1.4 beta and the new unit handling is driving me up the wall. _I absolutely hate it._ Sorry.

I have background in maths/physics so I do appreciate the attempt to be mathematically logical, etc. - but it gets in the way of usability and what might be called "casual expressiveness".

Like @tozz I'd like `18/14em` to just work.  Disallowing mixing units (i.e. `1px/1em`) makes a huge sense - but don't treat unitless values as having 'the empty unit' - and don't throw away units when dividing. It only makes everything more complicated and verbose and feel like programming in Java.

Please optimize for the most common case, and please don't break existing LESS code unnecessarily.

If I want a unitless ratio of `450em/15em` I'll wrap it in `unit()` to strip away the `em` bit.

</rant>
@maranomynet yes I plan to essentially do this before releasing 2.0
(hence high priority bug assigned to milestone 1.4 :) )
